//<![CDATA[
	var searchbox = MGJS.$("searchbox");
	var searchtxt = MGJS.getElementsByClassName("textfield", "input", searchbox)[0];
	var searchbtn = MGJS.getElementsByClassName("button", "input", searchbox)[0];
	var tiptext = "Type text to search here...";
	if(searchtxt.value == "" || searchtxt.value == tiptext) {
		searchtxt.className += " searchtip";
		searchtxt.value = tiptext;
	}
	searchtxt.onfocus = function(e) {
		if(searchtxt.value == tiptext) {
			searchtxt.value = "";
			searchtxt.className = searchtxt.className.replace(" searchtip", "");
		}
	}
	searchtxt.onblur = function(e) {
		if(searchtxt.value == "") {
			searchtxt.className += " searchtip";
			searchtxt.value = tiptext;
		}
	}

		if(searchtxt.value == "" || searchtxt.value == tiptext) {

	<div class="post" id="post-410">
		<h2>Positive log-likelihood values happen</h2>
		<div class="info">
			<span class="date">16 February 2011</span>
			<span class="author"><a href="http://blog.stata.com/author/icanette/" title="Posts by Isabel Canette, Senior Statistician">Isabel Canette, Senior Statistician</a></span>										<span class="comments"><a href="#disqus_thread">Go to comments</a></span>
						<div class="fixed"></div>
		</div>
		<div class="content">
			
<!-- Facebook Like Button v1.9.6 BEGIN [http://blog.bottomlessinc.com] -->
<iframe src="The%20Stata%20Blog%20%C2%BB%20Positive%20log-likelihood%20values%20happen_files/like.htm" allowtransparency="true" style="border: medium none; overflow: hidden; width: 450px; height: 30px; margin: 2px 0px;" frameborder="0" scrolling="no"></iframe>
<!-- Facebook Like Button END -->
<p>From time to time, we get a question from a user puzzled about 
getting a positive log likelihood for a certain estimation. We get so 
used to seeing negative log-likelihood values all the time that we may 
wonder what caused them to be positive.</p>
<p>First, let me point out that there is nothing wrong with a positive log likelihood.</p>
<p>The likelihood is the product of the density evaluated at the 
observations. Usually, the density takes values that are smaller than 
one, so its logarithm will be negative.  However, this is not true for 
every distribution.</p>
<p>For example, let’s think of the density of a normal distribution with a small standard deviation, let’s say 0.1.</p>
<pre>. di normalden(0,0,.1)
3.9894228
</pre>
<p>This density will concentrate a large area around zero, and therefore
 will take large values around this point. Naturally, the logarithm of 
this value will be positive.</p>
<pre>. di log(3.9894228)
1.3836466
</pre>
<p>In model estimation, the situation is a bit more complex. When you 
fit a model to a dataset, the log likelihood will be evaluated at every 
observation. Some of these evaluations may turn out to be positive, and 
some may turn out to be negative. The sum of all of them is reported.  
Let me show you an example.</p>
<p>I will start by simulating a dataset appropriate for a linear model.</p>
<div class="syntaxhighlighter  " id="highlighter_432123"><div class="bar"><div class="toolbar"><a class="item viewSource" style="width: 16px; height: 16px;" title="view source" href="#viewSource">view source</a><div class="item copyToClipboard"><embed id="highlighter_432123_clipboard" type="application/x-shockwave-flash" title="copy to clipboard" allowscriptaccess="always" wmode="transparent" flashvars="highlighterId=highlighter_432123" menu="false" src="The%20Stata%20Blog%20%C2%BB%20Positive%20log-likelihood%20values%20happen_files/clipboard.swf" height="16" width="16"></div><a class="item printSource" style="width: 16px; height: 16px;" title="print" href="#printSource">print</a><a class="item about" style="width: 16px; height: 16px;" title="?" href="#about">?</a></div></div><div class="lines"><div class="line alt1"><table><tbody><tr><td class="number"><code>1</code></td><td class="content"><code class="plain">clear</code></td></tr></tbody></table></div><div class="line alt2"><table><tbody><tr><td class="number"><code>2</code></td><td class="content"><code class="plain">program drop _all</code></td></tr></tbody></table></div><div class="line alt1"><table><tbody><tr><td class="number"><code>3</code></td><td class="content"><code class="plain">set seed 1357</code></td></tr></tbody></table></div><div class="line alt2"><table><tbody><tr><td class="number"><code>4</code></td><td class="content"><code class="plain">set obs 100</code></td></tr></tbody></table></div><div class="line alt1"><table><tbody><tr><td class="number"><code>5</code></td><td class="content"><code class="plain">gen x1 = rnormal()</code></td></tr></tbody></table></div><div class="line alt2"><table><tbody><tr><td class="number"><code>6</code></td><td class="content"><code class="plain">gen x2 = rnormal()</code></td></tr></tbody></table></div><div class="line alt1"><table><tbody><tr><td class="number"><code>7</code></td><td class="content"><code class="plain">gen y = 2*x1 + 3*x2 +1 + .06*rnormal()</code></td></tr></tbody></table></div></div></div>
<p>I will borrow the code for <b>mynormal_lf</b> from the book <a href="http://www.stata-press.com/books/ml4.html"><i>Maximum Likelihood Estimation with Stata</i></a> (W. Gould, J. Pitblado, and B.  Poi, 2010, Stata Press) in order to fit my model via maximum likelihood.</p>
<div class="syntaxhighlighter  " id="highlighter_605888"><div class="bar"><div class="toolbar"><a class="item viewSource" style="width: 16px; height: 16px;" title="view source" href="#viewSource">view source</a><div class="item copyToClipboard"><embed id="highlighter_605888_clipboard" type="application/x-shockwave-flash" title="copy to clipboard" allowscriptaccess="always" wmode="transparent" flashvars="highlighterId=highlighter_605888" menu="false" src="The%20Stata%20Blog%20%C2%BB%20Positive%20log-likelihood%20values%20happen_files/clipboard.swf" height="16" width="16"></div><a class="item printSource" style="width: 16px; height: 16px;" title="print" href="#printSource">print</a><a class="item about" style="width: 16px; height: 16px;" title="?" href="#about">?</a></div></div><div class="lines"><div class="line alt1"><table><tbody><tr><td class="number"><code>1</code></td><td class="content"><code class="plain">program mynormal_lf</code></td></tr></tbody></table></div><div class="line alt2"><table><tbody><tr><td class="number"><code>2</code></td><td class="content"><code class="spaces">        </code><code class="plain">version 11.1</code></td></tr></tbody></table></div><div class="line alt1"><table><tbody><tr><td class="number"><code>3</code></td><td class="content"><code class="spaces">        </code><code class="plain">args lnf mu lnsigma</code></td></tr></tbody></table></div><div class="line alt2"><table><tbody><tr><td class="number"><code>4</code></td><td class="content"><code class="spaces">        </code><code class="plain">quietly replace `lnf' = ln(normalden($ML_y1,`mu',exp(`lnsigma')))</code></td></tr></tbody></table></div><div class="line alt1"><table><tbody><tr><td class="number"><code>5</code></td><td class="content"><code class="plain">end</code></td></tr></tbody></table></div><div class="line alt2"><table><tbody><tr><td class="number"><code>6</code></td><td class="content"> </td></tr></tbody></table></div><div class="line alt1"><table><tbody><tr><td class="number"><code>7</code></td><td class="content"><code class="plain">ml model lf  mynormal_lf  (y = x1 x2) (lnsigma:)</code></td></tr></tbody></table></div><div class="line alt2"><table><tbody><tr><td class="number"><code>8</code></td><td class="content"><code class="plain">ml max, nolog</code></td></tr></tbody></table></div></div></div>
<p>The following table will be displayed:</p>
<pre>.   ml max, nolog

                                                  Number of obs   =        100
                                                  Wald chi2(2)    =  456919.97
Log likelihood =  152.37127                       Prob > chi2     =     0.0000

------------------------------------------------------------------------------
           y |      Coef.   Std. Err.      z    P>|z|     [95% Conf. Interval]
-------------+----------------------------------------------------------------
eq1          |
          x1 |   1.995834    .005117   390.04   0.000     1.985805    2.005863
          x2 |   3.014579   .0059332   508.08   0.000      3.00295    3.026208
       _cons |   .9990202   .0052961   188.63   0.000       .98864      1.0094
-------------+----------------------------------------------------------------
lnsigma      |
       _cons |  -2.942651   .0707107   -41.62   0.000    -3.081242   -2.804061
------------------------------------------------------------------------------
</pre>
<p>We can see that the estimates are close enough to our original parameters, and also that the log likelihood is positive.</p>
<p>We can obtain the log likelihood for each observation by substituting the estimates in the log-likelihood formula:</p>
<pre>. predict double xb

. gen double lnf = ln(normalden(y, xb, exp([lnsigma]_b[_cons])))

. summ lnf, detail

                             lnf
-------------------------------------------------------------
      Percentiles      Smallest
 1%    -1.360689      -1.574499
 5%    -.0729971       -1.14688
10%     .4198644      -.3653152       Obs                 100
25%     1.327405      -.2917259       Sum of Wgt.         100

50%     1.868804                      Mean           1.523713
                        Largest       Std. Dev.      .7287953
75%     1.995713       2.023528
90%     2.016385       2.023544       Variance       .5311426
95%     2.021751       2.023676       Skewness      -2.035996
99%     2.023691       2.023706       Kurtosis       7.114586

. di r(sum)
152.37127

. gen f = exp(lnf)

. summ f, detail

                              f
-------------------------------------------------------------
      Percentiles      Smallest
 1%     .2623688       .2071112
 5%     .9296673       .3176263
10%      1.52623       .6939778       Obs                 100
25%     3.771652       .7469733       Sum of Wgt.         100

50%     6.480548                      Mean           5.448205
                        Largest       Std. Dev.      2.266741
75%     7.357449       7.564968
90%      7.51112        7.56509       Variance       5.138117
95%     7.551539       7.566087       Skewness      -.8968159
99%     7.566199        7.56631       Kurtosis       2.431257
</pre>
<p>We can see that some values for the log likelihood are negative, but 
most are positive, and that the sum is the value we already know. In the
 same way, most of the values of the likelihood are greater than  one.</p>
<p>As an exercise, try the commands above with a bigger variance, say, 
1.  Now the density will be flatter, and there will be no values greater
 than  one.</p>
<p>In short, if you have a positive log likelihood, there is nothing 
wrong with that, but if you check your dispersion parameters, you will 
find they are small.</p>
			<div class="fixed"></div>
		</div>
		<div class="under">
			<span class="categories">Categories: </span><span><a href="http://blog.stata.com/category/statistics/" title="View all posts in Statistics" rel="category tag">Statistics</a></span>			<span class="tags">Tags: </span><span><a href="http://blog.stata.com/tag/log-likelihood/" rel="tag">log likelihood</a></span>		</div>
	</div>

onclick="DISQUS.dtpl.actions.fire('profile.show', 163126685, null); return false">                <img src="The%20Stata%20Blog%20%C2%BB%20Positive%20log-likelihood%20values%20happen_files/noavatar32.png" class="dsq-deferred-avatar" data-src="http://mediacdn.disqus.com/uploads/users/791/723/avatar32.jpg?1299508433" alt="">            </a>        </div>        <div id="dsq-comment-body-163126685" class="dsq-comment-body">            <div class="dsq-comment-header">                <span class="dsq-commenter-name">Nick Cox</span>                                <span class="dsq-collapsed-count">                                            1 comment collapsed                                    </span>                                <a href="#" class="dsq-collapse-toggle dsq-collapse" title="Collapse thread" onclick="DISQUS.dtpl.actions.fire('comments.collapse', 163126685); return false;"><span>Collapse</span></a>                <a href="#" class="dsq-collapse-toggle dsq-expand" title="Expand thread" onclick="DISQUS.dtpl.actions.fire('comments.expand', 163126685); return false;"><span>Expand</span></a>            </div>              <div class="dsq-comment-message" id="dsq-comment-message-163126685">                <div class="dsq-comment-text" id="dsq-comment-text-163126685">        Isabel's point can be pushed further by underlining that<br>probability densities have units of measurement. <br><br>Naturally, everyone knows about units of measurement. Somewhere in<br>your past there was, with probability 1, some fierce science<br>teacher who was scathing when you missed out the units of<br>measurement in some report. The point re-emerges in the standard<br>elementary statistics course when it is underlined that the units<br>of variance are the square of the original units of measurement,<br>which is grounds enough for introducing its square root, the<br>standard deviation. <br><br>However, I've often noticed statistical people not using the same<br>logic when talking about densities, and sometimes their colleagues<br>or students can end up confused. (Occasionally, they get confused<br>too.) <br><br>The underlying general idea I often explain in this way. Density<br>is amount of "stuff" in some "space". In physics, with density in<br>the classic sense, "stuff" is clearly mass and "space" is clearly<br>volume. Many social scientists might more commonly think of<br>something like population density, in which "stuff" is number of<br>people and "space" is area. In the present example, "stuff" is <br>probability and "space" is the support of the variable(s) in<br>question.  <br><br>In statistics, introductory courses usually insist on a<br>distinction between probabilities for discrete variables and<br>probability densities for continuous variables, and ne'er the<br>twain shall meet. (At higher levels, mathematically-oriented<br>statisticians who have ingested large doses of measure theory<br>sometimes insist that anything can be a density; it's just a case<br>of the underlying measure, which could be counting measure.)  <br><br>Focusing on the continuous case, the units of the density come<br>from working backwards from the fact that the total probability,<br>the integral over its support of the density function, must be 1<br>and must be unit-free and dimensionless. It follows that <br><br>units of density  = 1 / units of variable <br><br>In the univariate case, the probability can be considered as the<br>area under the density curve, and the argument can be made visual<br>by considering rectangles with sides the density and the variable. <br><br>So, the units of the density of "miles per gallon" are "gallons<br>per mile", however odd that may seem. <br><br>In the bivariate or multivariate case, the units we are talking<br>about are the product of the units of the individual variables,<br>which gets messy and unintuitive, but not intrinsically difficult<br>or problematic. If we were imagining the joint density of mpg and<br>weight in the auto dataset, the units would be 1 / (miles per<br>gallon * pounds). <br><br>Away from likelihood calculations, the issue often arises when<br>people get a density estimate from say -kdensity- and are puzzled<br>by densities above 1. In fact, people have been known to ask how<br>to "fix" the results, which they put down to some bug in<br>-kdensity-.<br><br>I'll add a puff for a small classic of exposition: <br><br>D. J. Finney. 1977. <br>Dimensions of statistics. <br>Journal of the Royal Statistical Society. Series C (Applied Statistics)<br>26: 285-289. <br><br>Naturally, even if you specify your units for densities, you can<br>still make mistakes. I read a thesis in which a candidate reported<br>a density for his soils of 2 mg/m^3. (Think of how much a cubic<br>metre of water weighs, and double it.) It is salutary to realise<br>that billion-fold errors are not reserved for cosmology or<br>finance, but are possible in your own backyard. <br><br>      </div>                        </div>                        <!-- edit box dynamically inserted here -->            <div id="dsq-append-edit-163126685"></div>                <div class="dsq-comment-footer">        <ul class="dsq-comment-actions">                        <li id="dsq-like-163126685">                <span class="dsq-like-thumb dsq-font">A</span>                <a href="#" onclick="DISQUS.dtpl.actions.fire('comments.like', this,163126685); return false">1                    Like            </a>            </li>                        <li class="dsq-comment-flag" style="visibility: hidden">                <a href="#" class="dsq-comment-flag dsq-font" onclick="return DISQUS.dtpl.actions.fire('comments.report', 163126685, false);">F</a>            </li>                    </ul>    </div>            <!-- reply box dynamically inserted here -->            <div id="dsq-append-reply-163126685"></div>        </div>    </li>    <!-- new replies dynamically inserted here -->    <li id="dsq-append-post-163126685"></li>                    <li id="dsq-comment-160522063" data-dsq-comment-id="160522063" class="dsq-comment dsq-clearfix        dsq-comment-is-parent        " style="margin-left:0px;">        <div class="dsq-avatar dsq-tt" title="Expand Maarten Buis's profile">            <a href="http://disqus.com/Maarten_Buis/" onclick="DISQUS.dtpl.actions.fire('profile.show', 160522063, null); return false">                <img src="The%20Stata%20Blog%20%C2%BB%20Positive%20log-likelihood%20values%20happen_files/noavatar32.png" class="dsq-deferred-avatar" data-src="http://mediacdn.disqus.com/uploads/users/783/7504/avatar32.jpg?1299255322" alt="">            </a>        </div>        <div id="dsq-comment-body-160522063" class="dsq-comment-body">            <div class="dsq-comment-header">                <a href="http://www.maartenbuis.nl/" target="_blank" class="dsq-commenter-name" rel="nofollow">Maarten Buis</a>                                <span class="dsq-collapsed-count">                                            2 comments collapsed                                    </span>                                <a href="#" class="dsq-collapse-toggle dsq-collapse" title="Collapse thread" onclick="DISQUS.dtpl.actions.fire('comments.collapse', 160522063); return false;"><span>Collapse</span></a>                <a href="#" class="dsq-collapse-toggle dsq-expand" title="Expand thread" onclick="DISQUS.dtpl.actions.fire('comments.expand', 160522063); return false;"><span>Expand</span></a>            </div>              <div class="dsq-comment-message" id="dsq-comment-message-160522063">                <div class="dsq-comment-text" id="dsq-comment-text-160522063">
        Nice post, things like these can really baffle a person for a 
while. It reminds me of a discussion I had a while ago where someone 
claimed that it was better to model proportions than percentages. He 
based that on looking at the BIC values, and they do result in a lot 
smaller BIC values:<br><br><pre>use <a href="http://fmwww.bc.edu/repec/bocode/c/citybudget.dta" rel="nofollow">http://fmwww.bc.edu/repec/boco...</a>, clear<br>reg governing noleft minorityleft houseval popdens<br>estat ic<br><br>gen prop_gov = governing * 100<br><br>reg prop_gov noleft minorityleft houseval popdens<br>estat ic<br></pre><br><br>It
 took me a while to first figure out myself what was going on, which is 
basicaly the same issue as the one discussed in this post, and than to 
convince that other person.      </div>                        </div>                        <!-- edit box dynamically inserted here -->            <div id="dsq-append-edit-160522063"></div>                <div class="dsq-comment-footer">        <ul class="dsq-comment-actions">                        <li id="dsq-like-160522063">                <span class="dsq-like-thumb dsq-font">A</span>                <a href="#" onclick="DISQUS.dtpl.actions.fire('comments.like', this,160522063);
